I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2006 Country Programming Mission, the Government of the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide assistance for preparing 
the Integrated Renewable Biomass Energy Development Project in five participating provinces of 
Heilongjiang, Henan, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, and Shanxi. The project preparatory technical assistance 
(PPTA) will prepare a project to meet PRC’s goals of improving ecological agriculture, promoting 
renewable  energy,  and  addressing  ADB’s  overarching  goals  of  poverty  reduction  and 
environmental sustainability. The concept paper was approved by the Vice President and included 
in the country strategy and program update.1 
 
2.  At the request of the Government, ADB fielded a fact-finding mission in January 2007. The 
Mission  held  discussions  with  representatives  of  the  Government  and  the  five  provinces. 
Understanding  was  reached  on  the  TA  impact,  outcome,  implementation  arrangements,  cost 
estimates, and consultant’s terms of reference. The TA design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.2  
II.  ISSUES 
3.  PRC is still largely rural, with abundant biomass resources including agricultural (crop and 
agro-processing) residues, and animal wastes amounting to about 2.5 billion tons per annum, of 
which 70% is livestock waste. These resources have enormous potential for sustainable production 
of bio-energy but are presently underutilized or used in ways that severely pollute the environment. 
The National Strategy for Renewable Rural Biomass Energy Development3 is due for completion in 
November 2007. The strategy will provide a framework to sustainably utilize these resources as 
well as develop additional resources for renewable energy production as part of the Government’s 
objective of constructing a new countryside, reducing reliance on fossil fuels, and significantly 
reducing environmental pollution.    
4.  Regarding livestock wastes, the Government has taken steps to strengthen regulation on 
emissions from medium- and large-scale production enterprises, which are the main polluters. To 
comply with these regulations, under current economic and regulatory conditions, the least-cost 
response for most enterprises will be the installation of conventional, “end of pipe” waste treatment 
facilities (anaerobic lagoons).4 This will achieve the objectives of the pollution control regulation but 
will also: (i) increase greenhouse gas emissions, thus exacerbating global climate change; and 
(ii) significantly reduce the availability of resources to generate renewable energy consistent with 
the National Strategy for Renewable Rural Biomass Energy Development. 
5.  Rural medium- and large-sized biogas digester establishment integrated with eco-agriculture 
systems is a sensible and cost-effective way to address both rural energy gaps and the rural 
nonpoint source pollution problem. Biogas is generated from animal wastes (the end result of the 
carbohydrate animal feed, which is produced from solar energy through photosynthesis) in an 
anaerobic condition. Integrated biogas technology has been used to encourage efficient use of 
nutrients, production of clean energy, lowering of farming costs, and opportunities for organic 
farming. The Government has provided exceptionally strong impetus to rural biogas renewable 
energy development in the 11th Five-Year Plan passed by the People’s Congress in February 2006. 
Additionally, the Government promulgated its Number 1 Policy Document on 21 February 2006 
entitled Decision on New Countryside Development, emphasizing that biogas system development in

rural areas as an important element. The results of the New Countryside Development are expected 
to be (i) advanced production methods, (ii) improved livelihoods, (iii) a civilized social atmosphere, 
(iv) clean and tidy villages, and (v) democratic management. The first, second, and fourth areas will 
benefit from the rural biogas system development. 
 
6.  PRC is in the process of developing and strengthening regulations to reduce the negative 
environmental  impact  of  intensive  livestock  production,  and  intends  to  use  a  combination  of 
regulations and economic instruments. In 1996, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) introduced a 
regulation requiring all new large-scale livestock farms to establish manure storage facilities. In 
1998, the State Environmental Protection Administration (SEPA) began to evaluate pollution from 
livestock  production,  and  in  1999,  a  new  division  focusing  on  environmental  pollution  from 
agriculture was established. In May 2001, the Government established environmental management 
regulations  for  the  livestock  industry,  and  in  January  2002,  it  established  pollutant  emission 
standards with regard to the breeding industry.5 A new regulation by SEPA on “Pollution Material 
Emission  Standard  for  Animal  and  Poultry  Industry”  became  effective  on  1  January  2003. 
Additionally, the Government’s program on renewable energy promotes the formulation of biogas 
from livestock waste.  
 
7.  ADB’s  ongoing  project,  Efficient  Utilization  of  Agricultural  Wastes  Project6  in  the  four 
provinces of Henan, Hubei, Jiangxi, and Shanxi, is supporting the construction of over 19,000 
small household biogas digesters and 16 medium- and large-sized livestock biogas plants. A pilot 
clean development mechanism (CDM) project has also been implemented in Henan province for 
12 pig farms. In addition to the physical implementation of various types of technologies, this 
project has played a catalytic role in rural household biogas system development. Since technical 
assistance (TA) development in 2000, awareness of household biogas system development has 
expanded  at  both  the  national  and  provincial  levels.  Project  activities,  ongoing  consultations, 
promotion and communication strategies, and ongoing government engagement have supported 
increased understanding of the multiple benefits of the household biogas system. In the areas 
where the project has operated, adoption and engagement by farmers have been dramatic.  
 
8.  The experiences learned from the implementation of Efficient Utilization of Agricultural 
Wastes Project show the need for: (i) the continuous promotion of local and national awareness of 
the advantages of the household biogas system development; (ii) extensive technical support and 
training  provided  to  establish  adequate  technical  services  to  ensure  the  sustainability  of 
established household biogas systems; and (iii) an energy and environmental monitoring plan 
implemented to monitor the impacts on air, water, and soil quality.  
 
9.  Having supported the successful development of rural household biogas systems in PRC, 
through the implementation of Efficient Utilization of Agricultural Wastes Project, it is evident that 
significant barriers exist for the development of medium-sized biogas digester systems for livestock 
farms. These barriers include the following: 
 
(i)  No  specific  policy  instruments  exist  to  promote  commercial  implementation  of 
anaerobic digester system for intensive livestock wastes treatment. The medium-
sized  biogas  system  is  capital-intensive  and  not  economically  viable  under  the 
current conditions; it would require additional financing through mechanisms such 
as CDM. The Renewable Energy Law favors the establishment of large-scale power

generators, only allowing the generators beyond 500 kilowatts to connect with grid, 
but most medium-sized biogas digesters can just generate 50–150 kilowatts of 
electricity.  
(ii)  Current national and provincial financial sources, and rural energy support services 
have  been  heavily  preoccupied  by  household  biogas  digesters,  and  insufficient 
attention has been paid to medium- and large-sized biogas systems although the 
latter is widely recognized as the future direction of rural energy development. 
(iii)  There  are  inadequate  technical  support  services  for  medium  and  large  biogas 
systems,  which  lead  to  poor  maintenance  and  a  shortened  life.  As  a  result, 
established biogas systems in some provinces have stopped operating. In addition, 
there is a shortage of capable design engineers because most of the engineers 
involved  with  medium-scale  digester  design  used  to  work  on  the  industrial 
wastewater treatment process, and do not have enough experience to deal with the 
complicated  physical  and  chemical  features  of  animal  manures.  This  limited 
technical capacity creates a bottleneck, limiting the rapid development of medium- 
and large-sized biogas digesters. 
(iv)  There  are  insufficient  technical  standards  and  procedures  to  ensure  effective 
engineering design, construction, and operation of medium- and large-sized biogas 
systems.  It  is  necessary  to  establish  the  guidelines  for  technical  support  and 
services  for  quality  control  of  these  systems,  including,  for  example,  design, 
engineering, operation and maintenance, and project implementation management. 
Guidelines  and  specifications  for  the  economic  characteristics,  diversity,  and 
suitability  of  existing  technology  options  to  local  situations  will  ensure  the 
effectiveness of the operation of medium- and large-scale biogas systems. 
(v)  Lack of enforcement of environmental laws at the local level because of economic 
pressure from the livestock operations has led many provinces to assume that direct 
discharge to anaerobic lagoons is the only solution.  
(vi)  Lack  of  cooperation  between  responsible  agencies  and  lack  of  coordinated 
institutional  arrangements  result  in  different  agencies  promoting  different 
technologies through different financial sources. 
(vii)  An appropriate mechanism or agroecological system to dispose of all the liquid and 
solid effluents from the biogas digester onto farmers’ fields should be tested and 
piloted. Otherwise, a high risk of secondary pollution from biogas establishment will 
occur.  
10.  Promoting environmental improvement and clean energy is one of the strategic areas in the 
2007–2008 country strategy and program update for ADB’s operations in PRC. The proposed 
Project will aim at removing the above barriers by increasing rural renewable energy services, 
reducing pollution from animal wastes, and developing the practice of utilizing biogas energy and 
sludge by-products. 
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA is reduced pollution from animal wastes through the sustainable use 
of biogas energy and fertilizer by-products. The outcome of the TA will be a project design for a 
loan, which responds to clients’ needs and fulfills ADB requirements and safeguard policies. The 
TA will assist the Government in preparing an investment project based on the Government’s initial 
proposal to address the technical, financial, and institutional barriers. The Project is expected to

4   
transform the market for waste treatment at intensive livestock and poultry farms through the 
sustainable implementation of anaerobic digester (biogas) systems by integrating the ecological 
agricultural  practices,  technology  service  systems,  and  demonstrating  replicable  economic 
incentives based on carbon finance.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will be implemented in two phases using a fully participatory approach. During the 
first  phase,  the  consultant  team  will  (i)  conduct  assessments  of  sector  policy,  institutions, 
strategies, and plans; (ii) appraise the project proposals from the Government; (iii) assess the wide 
range  of  problems  constraining  eco-agricultural  development,  including  analysis  of  biogas 
technology options; (iv) undertake wider stakeholder consultations and conduct social, poverty, 
institutional,  environmental,  and  other  necessary  assessments  and  surveys;  (v)  evaluate  the 
impact of the ongoing program in eco-agricultural development, including lessons learned; and (vi) 
based on assessments and surveys, in consultation with the stakeholders, confirm the project 
rationale, scope, and approach, which should be reflected in the project design and monitoring 
framework.  Phase one reviews and assessments need to clearly demonstrate the economic 
rationale for the proposed investment as a public sector operation, in terms of addressing failures 
or limitation of markets. 
13.  During the second phase, in consultation with the stakeholders, the consultant team will 
prepare a comprehensive feasibility report. The report will cover in detail project impact, outcome, 
outputs,  and  activities—including  financial,  economic,  social,  and  environmental  safeguards; 
relevant  sector  analysis;  the  role  and  institutional  capacity  of  key  participating  agencies; 
procurement; implementation arrangements; and crosscutting issues of poverty reduction, gender, 
good governance, and private sector development. Consultants will also be engaged to assist in 
developing CDM projects for all eligible subprojects among estimated 300 subprojects in five 
provinces. Key activities for each output are included in the TA design and monitoring framework 
(Appendix 1). 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $990,000 equivalent, of which the Government 
requested ADB to finance $650,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from 
ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will contribute $340,000 in kind for office space, 
counterpart staff, site transportation, and other services. Details of the cost estimates for the TA 
are provided in Appendix 2. The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MOA, which has extensive experience in administering externally assisted projects, will be 
the Executing Agency (EA) for the TA. A steering committee will be established and chaired by the 
vice minister of MOA, comprising senior officials from the Department of Development Planning; 
Department  of  Research,  Education  and  Rural  Environment;  and  the  Foreign  Economic 
Cooperation Center (FECC). The steering committee will meet monthly to guide and support the 
TA team in the project preparation. 
 
16.  A TA management office (TMO) will be established in the FECC to carry out day-to-day TA 
operations. The director of the Rural Energy Division at Department of Research, Education and 
Rural Environment of MOA will serve as the head of the TMO and function as the overall TA 
coordinator. The FECC, through TMO, will execute the TA implementation; and be responsible for 
day-to-day  communications  and  operational  matters  among  ADB,  consultants,  and  related

5
government agencies. The director of the Agriculture Division for FECC of MOA will serve as the 
executive director of the TMO, and lead a task force in FECC to be responsible for the preparation 
of proposals, feasibility studies, and safeguard documents (environment and social) for the whole 
Project under the close guidance of the Rural Energy Division and the steering committee.  
 
17.  Five TA implementation offices will be established in the respective agriculture departments 
of  Heilongjiang,  Henan,  Jiangsu,  Jiangxi,  and  Shanxi.  These  implementation  offices  will  be 
adequately equipped with qualified staff and financial resources. They will be responsible for 
subproject identification; provincial data collection; and preparation of provincial project proposals, 
feasibility studies, and safeguard documentation.  
 
18.  A  national  project  coordination  committee  will  be  established  in  Beijing  and  include 
representatives  from  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  MOA,  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission, SEPA, and other agencies concerned to strengthen interagency coordination. 
 
19.  At  the  provincial  level,  the  provincial  project  steering  committee,  consisting  of 
representatives from the Agriculture Bureau, Provincial Financial Bureau, Provincial Development 
and Reform Committee, Provincial Environmental Protection Bureau, and other relevant groups will 
be established. It will be led by a vice-governor, who is in charge of agriculture development.  
 
20.  The TMO, in consultation with the national and provincial steering committees and TA 
implementation  offices,  will  provide  the  necessary  guidance,  and  mobilize  the  appropriate 
consultants to review provincial and national project design documents (subprojects, environment, 
CDM, etc.) developed by the local provinces and the National Design Institute. 
 
21.  Implementation of the TA will take 6 months, which will be structured in two phases. The 
first phase is expected to be implemented from August to October 2007, while the second phase 
will be carried out from November 2007 to January 2008. 
 
22.  A total of 14 person-months of international and 40 person-months of national consulting 
services are required. The draft outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. A 
consulting firm will be engaged for all services including CDM related services according to ADB’s 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2006,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB. ADB will select and engage consultants on the basis of the 
quality of their proposals and the cost of the services to be provided (with quality cost ratio of 
80:20),  following  simplified  technical  proposal  procedures.  The  consultants  will  submit  (i)  an 
inception report 4 weeks after commencement of their services, (ii) an interim progress report 
within 12 weeks of TA implementation, (iii) draft final report within 20 weeks, and (iv) a final report 
within 24 weeks, after incorporating EA’s and ADB's comments.7 Equipment for the TA will be 
procured by the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2006, as amended 
from time to time), and will be handed over to the EA upon completion of the TA.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
23.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Integrated Renewable Biomass 
Energy Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
 
A.  Overall Scope of Work 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented in two phases. Phase 1 (3.0 months) will 
(i)  study  sector  performance,  problems,  and  opportunities;  (ii)  conduct  a  poverty  and  social 
analysis; (iii) appraise all the proposed subprojects; (iv) propose the preliminary project design; (v) 
examine  the  possibilities  for  public-private  partnership;  (vi)  document  the  important  lessons 
learned; and (vii) formulate the design and monitoring framework for the Project. In phase 2 
(3.0 months),  an  investment  proposal  for  the  Project  will  be  prepared  as  follows:  (i)  all  the 
necessary feasibility studies, initial environmental examination/environmental impact assessment, 
resettlement plans, and ethnic minority development plans will be strengthened and finalized; (ii) 
cost estimates and a financing plan will be prepared; (iii) economic and financial analyses will be 
conducted; (iv) an institutional analysis will be conducted for implementation arrangements and 
capacity development for the Project; (v) a financial management analysis and a consultation and 
participation plan will be developed; and (vi) a procurement plan will be formulated and bidding 
documents  prepared.  Through  both  phases  of  the  TA  implementation,  effective  stakeholder 
consultation and participation, and technology transfer, will be carried out. Workshops at the 
provincial level, and a workshop among the five participating provinces, will be held for active 
stakeholder  consultation  in  the  project  preparation,  and  to  further  transfer  the  technologies 
developed by the TA.     
 
B.  Reporting Requirements 
 
2.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within 4 weeks of 
the  commencement  of  the  TA,  (ii)  an  interim  report  to  be  submitted  12  weeks  after  TA 
commencement (at the end of phase 1), (iii) a draft final report to be submitted 20 weeks after TA 
commencement, and (iv) a final report to be submitted at the conclusion of the TA. The clean 
development mechanism (CDM) consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report 
within 4 weeks, (ii) a midterm report within 12 weeks, and (iii) a final report with at least five project 
design documents at the end of the 20th week. The consultants will submit all reports in English 
and Chinese languages—six copies each in English and Chinese languages to the Government, 
and three copies of the English version to the Asian Development Bank (ADB), including one 
electronic copy on a compact disc. 
 
3.  The draft final report will be structured in accordance with ADB’s format for the report and 
recommendation of the President, and will cover each topic by chapter sufficiently for ADB to 
prepare the report and recommendation of the President. The final report will reflect comments 
made by government agencies, ADB, and other relevant parties. 
 
C.  Terms of Reference  
 
4.  The TA will be carried out by a team of consultants, engaged through a firm. The TA will 
require 14 person-months of international and 40 person-months of national consulting services, 
including CDM related services. The TA is expected to start in August 2007 and be completed in 
January 2008.    
5.  Rural Biogas Energy Specialists (team leader, international, 6 person-months; deputy 
team leader, national, 6 person-months). The team leader, together with the deputy team leader, 
will have demonstrated experience in preparing and managing rural biogas projects in the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) and understanding of PRC’s livestock industry including livestock waste 
management, rural biogas technical conditions, and policies. They will coordinate all activities of

10   Appendix 3 
the consultants during TA implementation, including liaising with the Executing Agency (EA) and 
implementing agencies (IAs) as team leader/deputy team leader. The team leader will periodically 
report progress to the EA and ADB, and submit high-quality consolidated reports as specified in 
the terms of reference. In addition to the duties as team leader and deputy team leader, the 
following technical responsibilities will be carried out: (i) finalize the approach for the TA, including 
a detailed work plan and implementation schedule; and appropriately assign team members with 
the  necessary  work;  (ii)  analyze  current  situation,  performance  indicators,  key  problems,  and 
opportunities in the sector; (iii) analyze strategies, policies, programs, and plans, and previous 
activities for rural biomass renewable energy development; (iv) analyze lessons learned from 
completed or ongoing projects; (v) identify critical needs for optimizing the technical design for 
lowering treatment costs in the integrated system, and minimizing the slurry and sludge generation; 
and recommend necessary institutional and incentives related improvements to realizing reduced 
costs and improved technical services; (vi) assess existing and alternative organizational and 
design structures that integrate the livestock farm development, biogas digester establishment, and 
crop production; assess capacity to expand arrangements for biogas system construction and 
operation in line with eco-agriculture expansions; and, together with the farm system and extension 
services  specialist  and  counterparts,  identify  the  most  appropriate  and  effective  rural  circular 
economy  development  arrangements;  (vii)  together  with  the  economists/financial  specialists, 
assess  the  viability  of  candidate  subprojects;  (viii)  provide  guidance  and  mobilize  financial 
specialists, environment specialist, and biogas engineers as well as provincial governments on 
CDM-related issues; (ix) determine if each proposed subproject is justified in financial, economic, 
social,  and  environmental  terms;  (x)  formulate  preliminary  and  final  design  and  monitoring 
frameworks for the Project based on stakeholders, problem, objective, and alternative analyses; 
(xi) prepare selection criteria, review, and evaluation procedures for subprojects to be considered 
for loan funding under the Project; (xii) strengthen and finalize feasibility studies for the selected 
subprojects to be included in the Project; (xiii) prepare the inception, interim, draft final, and final 
reports; and (xiv) organize workshops at the provincial level, and a workshop among the five 
participating provinces for active stakeholder consultation in the project preparation.     
 
6.  Environment Specialists (international, 2 person-months; national, 4 person-months). An 
international environment specialist, together with a national environment specialist, both with 
formal  qualifications  in  environmental  impact  assessment  and  knowledge  of  PRC’s  laws  and 
regulations on agricultural and industrial pollution, will undertake the following: (i) together with the 
biogas design engineer and eco-farming consultant, assess the possible environmental impact of 
project intervention on slurry and sludge generation for different types of technologies and land 
applications; (ii) review national environmental regulations and standards related to livestock waste 
management,  including  nonpoint  source  pollution  management  regulations  at  national  and 
provincial levels, water quality discharge standards of livestock farms, biogas digester design 
standard, land planning regulations, and international conventions; (iii) assess the environmental 
implications from project intervention on waste utilization; evaluate livestock farms’ readiness to 
operate the biogas digester system, prospects for alternative pesticide application and organic 
fertilizer utilization; and identify needs and measures for strengthening the rural energy extension 
services to promote minimizing wastes generation; (iv) assess the nutrient balance from utilizing 
slurry as fertilizer, potential residues, and other processing wastes from the integrated system; and 
identify appropriate mitigating measures for waste minimization; (v) evaluate the potential impacts 
from the project activities (including soil excavation, spoil disposal, noise, and wastes) and identify 
appropriate  mitigation  measures;  (vi)  identify  an  appropriate  institutional  arrangement  and 
monitoring system to ensure the effective implementation of the rural circular system; (vii) for the 
representative  sample  subprojects,  prepare  summary  initial  environment  examination, 
environmental  management  plan  (including  description  of  each  mitigation  measure  and  cost 
estimate), environmental monitoring plan, institutional arrangements, implementation schedule, 
and public discussion; (viii) for non-sample subprojects, prepare the environmental assessment

Appendix 3   11
framework (including subprojects’ environmental selection criteria), and environmental assessment 
and  review  procedures;  and  (ix) summarize  the  lessons  and  experiences  learned  from  the 
implementation  of  environmental  and  energy  monitoring  plan  under  Efficient  Utilization  of 
Agricultural Wastes Project,1 and develop an environmental monitoring plan to measure the impact 
of the project intervention. 
 
7.  Economists/Financial  Specialists  (international,  3  person-months;  national  [two 
positions],  9  person-months).  The  consultants,  who  will  be  experienced  in  economics,  rural 
finance, financial management, and financial governance issues and full working knowledge of the 
Costab 322 software, will undertake the following economic and financial aspects.  
 
8.  Economic Aspect: (i) assess the economic implications of any policy and institutional 
issues as part of the analysis and alternatives in the midterm report; (ii) working with the team 
leader and deputy team leader, conduct appropriate sector analysis including problem analysis to 
identify  barriers  in  the  sustainable  development  of  integrated  biogas  system  at  the  livestock 
operation farms; (iii) review existing data on farmer incomes in the project area, in conjunction with 
the social development specialist; and conduct the baseline data review and survey to understand 
likely  trends  that  the  Project  would  have  on  farmer  incomes  and  welfare;  (iv)  carry  out 
microeconomic analysis of livestock enterprise production conditions and performance in relation 
to waste management and biogas installation; (v) assist the team leader in preparing the livestock 
enterprise selection criteria; (vi) conduct an appropriate economic analysis of the Project, both with 
and without carbon revenue; (vii) conduct sensitivity and risk analysis of possible pricing changes 
in factor inputs and output markets, including costs of water, fertilizers, energy, price of carbon 
credits, and labor; (viii) conduct a distribution analysis among key stakeholders of the costs and 
benefits of the Project; (ix) prepare the costing of project components and review the proposed 
investment  project  design  and  costs,  including  arrangements  and  costs  of  maintenance  and 
options for cost recovery, where applicable; (x) help the team leader identify quantitative and 
qualitative economic and other benefits of each component, and justify the overall project proposal; 
provide detailed analysis of the assumptions and methodology used for inclusion in the draft final 
report; and (xi) ensure that economic analyses are conducted in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
for the Economic Analysis of Projects.3  
 
9.  Financial Aspect: (i) assess how livestock enterprises in the proposed provinces have 
raised capital to develop their facilities from government, development banks, commercial banks, 
own capital, and foreign capital sources; (ii) assess reasons for limited access by potential rural 
enterprise  borrowers  to  commercial  banking, development  banking, and  other  formal  banking 
sources; (iii) using available information, identify channels for lending to commercial livestock 
enterprises, and assess lending performance to the sector—including lending volumes, types of 
businesses supported, and repayment performance; (iv) propose implementation arrangements for 
the Project, including the potential for public-private partnerships; (v) recommend the channel most 
suitable for lending to the farms under the proposed Project, justify its selection, and demonstrate 
how the selected channel will lower transaction costs; (vi) assess the financial performance of 
candidate farms to be supported or associated with the Project and assist in preparing criteria for 
selecting  financially  viable  livestock  enterprises;  (vii)  examine  ownership  and  management 
structures of the beneficiary livestock enterprises, identify any risks, and propose measures to

2  Costab 32 is a computer software program that helps financial analysis, project economist, and project engineers

12   Appendix 3 
address them; (viii) carry out a financial management assessment of the EA and implementing 
agencies to assess the affordability and suitability of financial management systems (including 
accounting  and  auditing),  and  fund  flow  arrangements  needed  to  efficiently  and  effectively 
implement  an  ADB-financed  project;  (ix)  assess  the  capabilities  of  the  borrower,  executing 
agencies, and implementing agencies to manage funds and disbursements; (x) produce COSTAB-
based project costs and a financing plan in the format required by ADB; (xi) verify the availability of 
counterpart funding; and (xii) appraise the financial analysis for revenue-generating commercial 
farms and nonproductive/support services with and without carbon revenue, and produce the 
financial analysis results required by ADB. 
 
10.   CDM  Specialists  (international,  3  person-months;  national,  13  person-months).  The 
consultants will support the preparation of CDM documents and necessary capacity building works. 
The consultants will undertake the following: (i) review the criteria set for selection of farms for 
CDM; (ii) review the proposed institutional modalities and make recommendations for institutional 
(including legal issues) setup for the CDM bundling agencies; (iii) provide inputs in designing the 
training/capacity building programs for implementing units, farm owners, and bundling agencies; 
and be the resource person to conduct this training; (iv) assist provinces to carry out survey of 
farms and review the findings; (v) develop the criteria for selection of farms for CDM; (vi) assess 
the farms based on the criteria and recommend farms suitable for CDM project/s; (vii) evaluate 
institutional arrangements for CDM under ADB’s Efficient Utilization of Agricultural Wastes Project; 
review other agriculture CDM precedents in PRC and propose one or more institutional setups for 
CDM bundling agency/ies; (viii) review (pre-) feasibility studies, environmental impact assessment 
reports, financial status, and other documents of the participating farms; and collect other data 
needed  for  CDM  applications;  (ix) prepare  and  review  CDM  manual  for  project  performance, 
monitoring and verification, quality control, and assurance; (x) prepare and review project design 
documents, including CDM monitoring plans, with assistance from other PPTA consultants; and 
conduct  stakeholders  consultations;  (xi)  provide  relevant  training  on  CDM  to  project 
implementation units, farms, bundling agencies, etc.; (xii) assist the bundling agencies in securing 
designated national agency approvals; (xiii) support biogas bundling agencies to hire operational 
entity/ies; (xiv) support biogas bundling agencies and farm owners during on-site validations; and 
(xv) address any questions/concerns raised by the operational entity/ies. 
 
11.  Biogas Design and Construction Engineer (national, 2 person-months). The consultant 
will undertake the following: (i) work closely with other consultants; review and assess national and 
international experience in medium-sized biogas digester design technologies, and the implications 
for  the  local  provinces’  situation;  (ii)  survey  how  current  biogas  design  and  construction 
technologies are being used in project provinces, analyze the advantages and drawbacks of the 
technologies; (iii) calculate and estimate the conversion efficiency and cost of various technologies, 
and address the readiness of the technologies for large-scale application in the project provinces; 
(iv) develop biogas digester design guidelines for use by the provinces’ subprojects; (v) assist in 
the survey and analysis of manure types, local climate situation, and technology options in the 
project provinces; and provide recommendations regarding priority technologies, based on local 
conditions  in  project  provinces;  (vi)  appraise  the  technical  and  design  soundness  of  the 
representative sample subprojects, and develop criteria to assess the technical feasibility of non-
sample projects; (vii) identify capacity strengthening needs relating to biogas digester design, 
construction, and operation for the project provinces; (viii) work with the eco-farming specialist to 
review the enterprises and provincial proposals to meet the likely needs of the biogas systems for 
ongoing technical support; (ix) recommend revisions to the enterprise and provincial proposals for 
biogas service centers to ensure achievement of the proposed project objectives; (x) contribute to 
the draft final report preparation from a technical design perspective, and to CDM project design 
document preparation; and conduct other related work as assigned by the team leader; and (xi) 
make presentations at the necessary TA workshops and seminars.

Appendix 3   13
 
12.   Livestock Waste Management Specialist (national, 2 person-months). The consultant will 
undertake  the  following:  (i)  assess  performance  of  livestock  industry  development  in  the  five 
project  provinces  (together  with  the  economist);  (ii)  together  with  the  environment  specialist, 
examine the current level of compliance of livestock commercial farms, etc., with national and 
provincial livestock waste discharge standards; (iii) appraise the pre-feasibility proposals, as well 
as  the  financial  analysis  from  the  technical  livestock  management  and  manure  management 
aspects; and (iv) assist the team leader in preparing the farm enterprise selection criteria. 
 
13.  Eco-Farming Specialist (national, 2 person-months). The consultant will undertake the 
following: (i) review the enterprises and provincial proposals from the perspective of the potential 
for development of eco-agricultural (“circular” economy) systems; (ii) evaluate current level of 
awareness among medium- and large-sized commercial livestock farms on integrated farming 
systems  and  sustainable  manure  management;  (iii)  identify  capacity  gaps  that  need  to  be 
addressed in order to achieve the project outcome; (iv) carry out a demand analysis for extension 
services and determine willingness to pay for such services; (v) examine the extent to which the 
agriculture research and demonstration institutions to be supported under the proposed Project are 
able  to  meet  the  demand  for  extension  and  demonstration  services;  (vi)  clarify  the  role  of 
demonstration  farms;  (vii)  examine  the  balance  between  the  proposed  investment  on 
demonstration (model) farms and commercial farms; (viii) recommend revisions to the enterprises 
and  provincial  proposals  for  eco-agricultural  service  centers  to  ensure  achievement  of  the 
proposed  loan  project  objectives;  (ix)  review  the  extension/capacity  building  proposals  of  the 
demonstration farms and suggest a monitoring system for the demonstration activities; (x) design a 
study/exchange visit program among the project provinces; and (xi) assist the team leader in 
preparing the farm enterprise selection criteria. 
 
14.  Social Development Specialist (national, 2 person-months). The consultant will undertake 
the following: (i) prepare a poverty and social assessment of the beneficiaries and stakeholders, 
identifying any gender issues; (ii) identify any instances where proposed activities will trigger the 
need for land acquisition, changes in land use and/or restricted access to land that will entail 
involuntary resettlement; and prepare needed plans that meet ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement 
Policy (1995) and other related safeguard requirements; (iii) assess the numbers and status of any 
ethnic minorities in the project area and prepare the appropriate ethnic minority development plans 
in line with ADB’s safeguard policies, as needed; (iv) establish the baseline against which the 
project impacts on welfare and gender may be monitored with appropriate monitoring indicators, 
help design the repeat households survey to be carried out during implementation, and support the 
team leader in designing a sound monitoring system to track project implementation and use of 
resources; (v) support the economist to review existing data on farmer incomes in the project area, 
and conduct a survey to understand likely trends that the Project would have on farmer incomes 
and welfare; (vi) determine adequate cultural indicators for monitoring project impact on affected 
ethnic minorities as the Project progresses; (vii) review relevant private sector interactions with 
farmers in the project areas and identify possible roles for farmers during project implementation; 
and (viii) provide inputs to the project design that address the constraints identified in the social 
and poverty assessment and review of the farming and marketing systems.
